nodes.bodyText: Return directly return new PartitionedMapTable(mapName, e); instead of doing this on the higher level?
Do we have to expose here LinkedHashMap? Maybe Map is enough?
Order of fields is important for us, LinkedHashMap reflects that.

checkException() is needed to let optimizer know that the table exists, but is not functional. Descriptors are used after the optimization process, so an exception check is not needed here. To summarize, exception check is only needed in the overridden methods.
Maybe, but again - exceptions are needed by Calcite integration, that works with Table interface, and never touch extension methods.
Is there any specific reason for using portable style resolution only for binary? If user would change the storage format, we may end up with a different schema.

The idea is as follows:

Background: in HZ key is always stored as Data, value is stored as either object or key. Portable object exposes different fields depending on whether we process it as object or as Data
If the format is OBJECT, we always deserialize to real objects
If the format is BINARY, we do not deserialize portables
This works almost in the same way as in Predicate API with one difference: if both key and value as Portables and storage format is OBJECT, then we extract Java fields form both key and value, while in Predicate API we extract portable fields from key, and Java fields from value.
Our approach looks more consistent to me - user asked us to store key-value pairs In a form of Java objects, and we expose fields of Java objects from both key and value.

Another option is to resolve the schema for OBJECT format using the portable definition, but read the values from the Java object itself (I think it was done this way for performance reasons). But that might produce even more weird behavior, looks like we can't do anything about it.
The problem is that portable definition may differ from real Java fields.
